docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: To satisfy President Bush's call for universal health insurance, Ted Halstead wants to make it mandatory (''To Guarantee Universal Coverage, Require It,'' Op-Ed, Jan. 31). He wants to enroll the uninsured ''in a default private plan by the government, and either billed or subsidized accordingly.'' This would be tough to enforce. In Mr. Halstead's model, noninsurance would be disclosed on tax returns next year; what about sick or injured scofflaws in the interim? And what about the millions who don't file Form 1040's?

headline.main: Health Insurance for All (and Meaning It)

docs.abstract: John Glasel letter criticizes Ted Halstead's proposal for universal health insurance (Jan 31 Op-Ed) and favors expanding Medicare to cover everyone
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    To satisfy President Bush's call for universal health insurance, Ted Halstead wants to make it mandatory (''To Guarantee Universal Coverage, Require It,'' Op-Ed, Jan. 31). He wants to enroll the uninsured ''in a default private plan...

docs.lead_paragraph: The crazy-quilt pattern of medical financing in this country often makes it impossible to tell what a patient is really paying for and whether the price is fair. That is especially true in the case of cancer doctors who provide chemotherapy treatments in offices and clinics outside the hospital setting. As Reed Abelson of The Times reported recently, cancer doctors buy these drugs at discount prices but bill the patients and their insurers at much higher rates, making a substantial profit on the differential.
docs.abstract: Editorial on doctors who make profit on chemotherapy drugs says best solution would be for Medicare to pay the real wholesale price for the drugs and adjust its formula to pay doctors full cost of administering them
docs.snippet: The crazy-quilt pattern of medical financing in this country often makes it impossible to tell what a patient is really paying for and whether the price is fair. That is especially true in the case of cancer doctors who provide chemotherapy...

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. James E. McGreevey insisted today that he would not consider any increase in the state's three major taxes, but many state legislators, responding grimly to the stripped-down budget he presented on Tuesday, said they would listen to any proposals to alleviate the pain in it. And while Mr. McGreevey rejects proposals to establish a new marginal tax rate on incomes over $500,000 or $1 million, which several other states are considering, the term ''millionaire's tax'' was circulating today as never before.

headline.main: Trenton Lawmakers Seek Alternatives to McGreevey's Austere Budget Plan

docs.abstract: New Jersey Gov James McGreevey reiterates that he will not consider increase in state's major taxes even though budget he presented is austere and cuts numerous programs; idea of tax on incomes exceeding $500,000 or $1 million gains is gaining momentum among legislators (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Forcing all Americans to buy health coverage would not drive down coverage. As the laws of economics tell, increase the demand, and the prices will go up. Ted Halstead's plan (Op-Ed, Jan. 31) would force millions of Americans who have made a choice about their needs to buy coverage they may or may not need.

headline.main: Health Insurance for All (and Meaning It)

docs.abstract: Christopher Bowen letter says that forcing all Americans to buy health coverage would not drive down cost, because increasing demand means that prices will go up
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Forcing all Americans to buy health coverage would not drive down coverage. As the laws of economics tell, increase the demand, and the prices will go up.     Ted Halstead's plan (Op-Ed, Jan. 31) would force millions of Americans...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I appreciate Ted Halstead's attempt at solving our health care crisis (Op-Ed, Jan. 31). But there is a flaw in his plan. If we require all young individuals to buy insurance, the premiums would pay for only the medical resources they use. This would have no impact on the cost of health insurance for older individuals. If we require them to pay premiums higher than the resources they use, then we are taxing them to help offset higher costs for older individuals.

headline.main: Health Insurance for All (and Meaning It)

docs.lead_paragraph: A POWERFUL hurricane tears through Florida. A nuclear power plant fails.
docs.abstract: Rapidly evolving set of conceptual and computing tools allows mathematicians, engineers and insurance executives to assess risks of what are known as low-probability, high-consequence events, such as hurricanes, space shuttle failures and other disasters; field, known as probabilistic risk assessment, helps companies and government agencies decide whether to take certain chances; concepts were developed 40 years ago, but recent advances in computing power have increased use of such analyses and confidence in them; idea behind it is that mathematics can help determine chances of particular outcome based on what is known about smaller variables that lead to those outcomes; examples cited; photos (L)
docs.snippet: A POWERFUL hurricane tears through Florida.     A nuclear power plant fails.

docs.lead_paragraph: HCA, the hospital chain, reported today that it lost $102 million in the fourth quarter because of a $631 million settlement with the federal government over allegations of health care fraud. The company said the loss amounted to 20 cents a share for the quarter, in contrast to net income of $59 million, or 11 cents a share, last year.

headline.main: HCA Reports a Loss of $102 Million

docs.abstract: HCA reports loss of $102 million in fourth quarter because of $631 million settlement with government over allegations of health care fraud; revenue increased 10.7 percent, to $5 billion from $4.5 billion year earlier; company earned $833 million in 2002, down from $956 million year ago; revenue increased about 10 percent, to $19.7 billion, up from $18 billion (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A former Republican Party boss is portraying himself in trial testimony as the reluctant conduit for kickbacks to Nassau's chief deputy county executive in a multimillion-dollar health insurance scandal. ''It looked like a bribe, it sounded like a bribe,'' William Michael Blake testified. ''I practically fell off my chair.'' He was in United States District Court in Central Islip on Monday as he recalled being told to pass along the payoffs.

headline.main: Ex-G.O.P. Boss on Trial Says He Funneled Bribes Reluctantly

docs.abstract: Former Suffolk County Republican Party boss William Michael Blake portrays himself in trial testimony as reluctant conduit for kickbacks to Nassau's Chief Deputy County Exec Robert J McDonald in multimillion-dollar health insurance scandal; Blake has admitted his own guilt and testifies as prosecution witness in trial of main defendant Robert E Isernio; case reviewed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The spectacle of thousands of physicians hitting the bricks this week in New Jersey is a sobering measure of doctors' fury at the rising costs of malpractice insurance. But their proposed solution of a $250,000 cap on pain-and-suffering litigation is far too simplistic a prescription as the doctors attempt to pressure the state government for a quick fix. The physicians have been careful to limit their strike to non-emergency care, and they have legitimate concerns about malpractice premiums, which have been spiking upward, reaching more than $100,000 for some specialists. They blame trial lawyers for obtaining ''jackpot'' awards of millions of dollars in non-economic damages from sympathetic juries. The trial lawyers, already demonized by President Bush in his demand for tight tort reform, insist the basic problem is that the insurance industry is allowed to compensate for heavy investment losses with carte blanche premium hikes on all doctors, good and bad.

headline.main: The Doctor Is Out in New Jersey

docs.abstract: Editorial opposes $250,000 cap on pain-and-suffering litigation sought by doctors in New Jersey striking over malpractice insurance rates; says commission should be appointed to come up with unbiased information on problem (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. James E. McGreevey, in an angry and frustrated address to legislators, today presented a budget for next year that cuts deeply into state programs and calls for tax and fee increases that have already drawn protests. Mr. McGreevey's $23.7 billion plan closes a deficit he projected at $5 billion for the year starting July 1 -- a gap that is among the highest in the nation, even in a year that fiscal experts say is the worst for state finances since World War II.

headline.main: New Jersey Gets a Budget No One Likes

docs.abstract: Gov James E McGreevey, in angry and frustrated address to legislators, presents budget for next year that cuts deeply into state programs and calls for tax and fee increases that have already drawn protests; McGreevey's projected $23.7 billion plan closes deficit he projected at $5 billion for year starting July 1--gap that is among highest in nation; McGreevey says his budget contains 'cuts that I abhor and eliminates programs that I support'; McGreevey's plan would eliminate property-tax relief for about 300,000 homeowners who make over $100,000 a year, cut health insurance for almost 60,000 low-income adults, and suspend all grants to arts groups and for science and technology and force tuition increases at every state college and university; budget also proposes highest state cigarette tax in nation, at $1.90 a pack, and cuts antismoking programs; table shows new sources of revenue for McGreevey's budget and savings and program cuts; photo (M)
